question: What kind of structure contains hundreds of billions of stars?

content.source_1: In 1923–1924, Edwin Hubble measured Cepheid variable stars in the Andromeda “nebula” and showed it lies far beyond the Milky Way, establishing that spiral nebulae are external galaxies.
content.source_2: A galaxy is a gravitationally bound stellar system containing millions to billions of stars.
content.source_3: Globular clusters are dense, nearly spherical star systems that typically contain hundreds of thousands to a few million stars.
content.source_4: By the 1920s, astronomers had cataloged over a hundred globular clusters in the Milky Way after resolving many “nebulae” into swarms of stars with large telescopes.
content.source_5: The 1920 Shapley–Curtis “Great Debate” asked whether spiral nebulae were nearby gas clouds or distant “island universes”; Hubble’s distance measurements settled the issue in favor of external galaxies.
content.source_6: Open clusters in the Milky Way generally contain only hundreds to thousands of stars, unlike globular clusters or galaxies.
